channel.title: Reading and Writting XML
channel.description:
Well serveral people i have spoken to have said that Java handling of XML is slow and CPU consuming. Compared to the alternate ways for reading and writting, is using XML a better choice?
Because i spent some time learning it when i was creating websites and it would be rather helpful in my programming :)

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

If size is an issue then just zip/gzip it on the fly.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

I recommend Xerces still. Unified XML parsing/creating/modifying Xalan-Xerxes.

I think JDOM is uses Xerces to do the parsing or JAXP.

I recommend sticking with IBM verses SUN’s offering.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Unhandled:

You shouldn’t have to use 3rd party library to read a simple XML document.

SAX and DOM are in the java standard library, (but never use DOM, for reasons i’ve explained before)

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

XML is indeed a great way to store data, but I honestly dread using it with Java. Maybe it’s because I suck at Java, but it’s just not easily done. You shouldn’t have to use 3rd party library to read a simple XML document.

I could say something about .NET’s XML capabilities, but I won’t bother.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

DOM is rubbish for java programmers,

DOM code

DocumentFactory docfac = DocumentFactoryMaker.getFactory();
Document doc = docfac.newDocument();
ElementFactory elemfac = ElementFactoryMaker.getFactory();
Element rootElement = elemfac.newElement("doc");
rootElement.setText(TextFactory.fromString("text in element"));

[size=7pt]note: these are not the names the DOM library uses, but you get the idea of the structure[/size]

equivalent code in JDOM

Document doc = new Document();
Element rootElement = new Element("doc");
rootElement.setText("text in element");
doc.setRootELement(rootElement);

as you can see the JDOM code makes much more sence to a java programmer,
if you’re wondering why DOM is so bad, its because it was meant to work on many languages other then java, some which didnt even have OOP,

think about it this way, if DOM was so incredible, why did they bother to make JDOM?

as for size, you should see how bloated MS word documents are,

and a Binary XML is the shittest idea ever, it defeats the entire point of xml,
think about it this way ruler, if Binary XML was such a good idea, someone would have already made it (in fact people have tried to make it, but its never adopted cause everyone else realises how fail it is)

if you’re trying to optimize for size, you wont use xml, or a Binary XML, but a complete binary solution, which will lose all the advantages of xml,

as for bandwidth, you should see how much is “wasted” by VoIP and video applications,
do you know of an email protocol called POP, it was made quite a long time ago, its a text based protocol, similar to IRC in some ways, and its for reading (but not writing) emails,

it has some very dirty hacks there to make it work, commands are separated by newlines, but emails contain newlines… so POP does very un-elegant things,
POP has gone about 6 or 7 revisions, and its still sometimes used today, and if you’re lucky, you wont get mixed up with versions,

if they used XML in the first place, they wouldn’t have all this dirty cracking, because xml is extensible, they could have very easily added new fixes and features without breaking old systems, and there is no greasy hack to make newlines work either,

I’m a big fan of elegance,
there elegance in mathematical theorems, elegance in chemistry techniques, and elegance in programming,

when it comes to elegance, xml is king.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

I like to writt a lot. Srsly, use xerces, I never had any problems with it.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

XML parsing breaks down into SAX or DOM. DOM stores the entire xml document in a tree structure. SAX just reads each element to you with a attributies list, etc. Up to you remember parent elements.

http://xerces.apache.org/xerces2-j/

The biggest problem with XML is the size especially in bandwidth constrained areas. What is needed is a Binary XML.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

Yeah ive always read XML through regex. That’s never been slow, so I would expect a properly written library to be fairly fast and efficient.
XML is alrite, but it annoys the crap out of me. For example MSN protocol is now all XML, WHY? WHY? why couldn’t they stick to how it was!

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I think regular expressions with a bit of java for getting the structure right would be more than sufficient. Can’t really see how that would be so slow that you would possibly notice it.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading and Writting XML
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

xml is fucking secks, for most things, there are exceptions of course, but for most things, it is fucking secks

as for reading it with java, you might want http://www.cafeconleche.org/books/xmljava/
also a very nice library http://www.jdom.org/

also there is this library which comes with java, it has a different structure to JDOM, you can stream the xml, if you want to use less processing power, use this one for reading, it cannot write xml http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/org/xml/sax/package-summary.html

its quite likely that other people will attack xml on this thread,
so please do, cause ill defend it to the hilt, and i like debating

Read full topic
